009
010package imagingbook.lib.math.eigen;
011
012import static imagingbook.lib.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
013
014import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
015
016
017/**
018 * Implements an efficient, closed form algorithm for calculating the real 
019 * eigenvalues (&lambda;) and eigenvectors (x) of a 2x2 matrix of the form
020 * <pre>
021 *   | a b |
022 *   | c d | </pre>
023 * There are typically (but not always) two pairs of real-valued 
024 * solutions 
025 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>0</sub>&rang;,
026 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>1</sub>&rang;
027 * such that A&middot;x<sub>k</sub> = &lambda;<sub>k</sub>&middot;x<sub>k</sub>.
028 * The resulting eigensystems are ordered such that
029 * &lambda;<sub>0</sub> &ge; &lambda;<sub>1</sub>.
030 * Eigenvectors are not normalized, i.e., no unit vectors
031 * (any scalar multiple of an Eigenvector is an Eigenvector too).
032 * Non-real eigenvalues are not handled.
033 * Clients should call method {@link #isReal()} to check if the 
034 * eigenvalue calculation was successful.
035 * <p>
036 * This implementation is inspired by Blinn, Jim: "Jim Blinn's Corner: 
037 * Notation, Notation, Notation", Morgan Kaufmann (2002) -
038 * Ch. 5 ("Consider the Lowly 2x2 Matrix").
039 * Note that Blinn uses the notation 
040 * x&middot;A = &lambda;&middot;x for the matrix-vector product (as common in computer graphics),
041 * while this implementation uses 
042 * A&middot;x = &lambda;&middot;x.
043 * Thus x is treated as a column vector and matrix A is transposed (elements b/c are exchanged).
044 * </p>
045 * This implementation is considerably (ca. factor 5) faster than the general solution
046 * available in {@link EigensolverNxN} (based on Apache Commons Math) for 2x2 matrices.
047 * 
048 * @author W. Burger
049 * @version 2022/02/18
050 * 
051 */
052public class Eigensolver2x2 implements RealEigensolver { // to check: http://www.akiti.ca/Eig2Solv.html
053        
054        private final boolean isReal;
055        private final double[] eVals = {Double.NaN, Double.NaN};
056        private final double[][] eVecs = new double[2][];
057        
058        /**
059         * Constructor, takes a 2x2 matrix.
060         * @param A a 2x2 matrix
061         */
062        public Eigensolver2x2(double[][] A) {
063                this(A[0][0], A[0][1], A[1][0], A[1][1]);
064                if (Matrix.getNumberOfRows(A) != 2 || Matrix.getNumberOfColumns(A) != 2) {
065                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix not of size 2x2");
066                }
067        }
068        
069        /**
070         * Constructor, takes the individual elements of a 2x2 matrix A:
071         * <pre>
072         *   | a b |
073         *   | c d | </pre>
074         * @param a matrix element A[0,0]
075         * @param b matrix element A[0,1]
076         * @param c matrix element A[1,0]
077         * @param d matrix element A[1,1]
078         */
079        public Eigensolver2x2(double a, double b, double c, double d) {
080                isReal = solve(a, b, c, d);
081        }
082        
083        @Override
084        public int getSize() {
085                return 2;
086        }
087        
088        private boolean solve(final double a, final double b, final double c, final double d) {
089                final double R = (a + d) / 2;
090                final double S = (a - d) / 2;
091                final double rho = sqr(S) + b * c;
092                
093                if (rho < 0) {  
094                        return false;           // no real-valued eigenvalues
095                }
096                
097                final double T = Math.sqrt(rho);
098                final double lambda0 = R + T;   // eigenvalue 0
099                final double lambda1 = R - T;   // eigenvalue 1
100                final double[] x0, x1;                  // eigenvectors 0, 1
101                
102                if (a - d > 0) {
103//                      System.out.println("Case 1");
104                        x0 = new double[] {S + T, c};
105                        x1 = new double[] {b, -(S + T)};
106                }
107                else if (a - d < 0) {
108//                      System.out.println("Case 2");
109                        x0 = new double[] {b, -S + T};
110                        x1 = new double[] {S - T, c};
111                }
112                else {          // (A - D) == 0
113//                      System.out.println("Case 3");
114                        final double bA = Math.abs(b);
115                        final double cA = Math.abs(c);
116                        final double bcR = Math.sqrt(b * c);
117                        if (bA < cA) {                                                  // |b| < |c|
118//                              System.out.println("Case 3a");
119                                x0 = new double[] { bcR, c};
120                                x1 = new double[] {-bcR, c};
121                        }
122                        else if (bA > cA) {                                     // |b| > |c|
123//                              System.out.println("Case 3b");
124                                x0 = new double[] {b,  bcR};
125                                x1 = new double[] {b, -bcR};
126                        }
127                        else {  // |B| == |C| and B,C must have the same sign
128//                              System.out.println("Case 3c");
129                                if (cA > 0) {   // 
130                                        x0 = new double[] { c, c};
131                                        x1 = new double[] {-c, c};
132                                }
133                                else { // B = C = 0; any vector is an eigenvector (we don't return trivial zero vectors)
134                                        x0 = new double[] { 0, 1};      // pick 2 arbitrary, orthogonal vectors
135                                        x1 = new double[] { 1, 0};
136                                }
137                        }
138                }
139                
140                eVals[0] = lambda0;
141                eVals[1] = lambda1;
142                eVecs[0] = x0;
143                eVecs[1] = x1;
144                
145                // lambda0 >= lambda1, no need to sort by magnitude
146                
147//              if (Math.abs(lambda0) >= Math.abs(lambda1)) {   // order eigenvalues by magnitude
148//                      eVals[0] = lambda0;
149//                      eVals[1] = lambda1;
150//                      eVecs[0] = x0;
151//                      eVecs[1] = x1;
152//              }
153//              else {
154//                      eVals[0] = lambda1;
155//                      eVals[1] = lambda0;
156//                      eVecs[0] = x1;
157//                      eVecs[1] = x0;
158//              }
159                return true;    // real eigenvalues
160        }
161        
162        @Override
163        public boolean isReal() {
164                return isReal;
165        }
166        
167        @Override
168        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
169                return eVals;
170        }
171        
172        @Override
173        public double getEigenvalue(int k) {
174                return eVals[k];
175        }
176        
177
178        @Override
179        public double[][] getEigenvectors() { // TODO: needs to be tested!
180                return Matrix.transpose(eVecs);
181        }
182        
183        @Override
184        public double[] getEigenvector(int k) {
185                return eVecs[k].clone();
186        }
187        
188        @Override
189        public String toString() {
190                if (this.isReal) {
191                        return String.format("<%.4f, %.4f, %s, %s>", 
192                                eVals[0], eVals[1], Matrix.toString(eVecs[0]), Matrix.toString(eVecs[1]));
193                }
194                else {
195                        return "<not real>";
196                }
197        }
198        
199        // ----------------------------------------------------
200        
201        public static void main(String[] args) {
202                
203                double[][] M = Matrix.multiply(0.1, Matrix.idMatrix(2)); 
204                Eigensolver2x2  es = new Eigensolver2x2(M);
205                System.out.println(Matrix.toString(es.getEigenvalues()));
206                System.out.println(Matrix.toString(es.getEigenvector(0)));
207                System.out.println(Matrix.toString(es.getEigenvector(1)));
208        }
209                
210}
